{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3298751,"name":"Guilherme Samuel","username":"megarubber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/megarubber/{size}/172063_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-31T17:42:09.226Z","cooked":"

Is there a form to use a “brushless PWM controller” to control NEO for testing? Recently, we got a generic PWM controller that has a potentiometer to control to test our CIM motors (here’s the thread that helped me), so I’d like if we could do something similar.

I know that it’s recommend only on SparkMax (docs says this) and we won’t use on competition.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-01-31T17:42:09.226Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":33,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":188.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":452795,"topic_slug":"using-a-generic-pwm-controller-on-neo","display_username":"Guilherme Samuel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/test-cim-motor-without-roborio/451204","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Test CIM motor without RoboRIO","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-generic-pwm-controller-on-neo/452795/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3298757,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-31T17:48:07.693Z","cooked":"

Spark Maxes support PWM control. All you need to do is hook one up to your servo tester, make sure it’s in brushless mode, and you’ll be able to use it to run a NEO.

docs.revrobotics.com

SPARK MAX Control Interfaces

yeah, but I would like to use another controller instead of SparkMax, and (preference) without PDP/PDH.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-02-08T01:47:08.678Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":35.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452795,"topic_slug":"using-a-generic-pwm-controller-on-neo","display_username":"Guilherme Samuel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28014,"username":"bobbysq","name":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-generic-pwm-controller-on-neo/452795/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3304594,"name":"Tinnittin","username":"Tinnittin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tinnittin/{size}/148604_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-08T01:58:44.473Z","cooked":"

There are no other controllers designed for NEOs besides the ones that REV sells. You don’t need to connect the SparkMax to the PDP/PDH, but I’d recommend having some kind of fuse in line. You can then control the SparkMax through the REV Hardware Client or using a PWM generator such as the Thrifty Throttle
